(Particulars)

Column: 464



    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, there are 2,449 national servicemen with School Certificate, Higher School Certificate, Diploma or Degree qualifications who have completed national service. Of these, 1,144 left the Singapore Armed Forces before teh Direction of Employmnet Scheme was introduced. WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION
ACT
(Amending legislation for enhanced compensation)


    2. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minster for Labour if he will introduce legislation to amend the Workmen's Compensation Act (Chapter 130)

Column: 465

(i) to ensure that a workman who suffers permanently disabling injury is compensated for loss of earnings, medical costs, rehabilitation, pain, suffering, shock, loss of standing in the community, humiliation, mortification and all other forms of tangible and intangible ill-effects; and (ii) to entitle a permanently disabled workman to monetary compensation exceeding several-fold the rates and sums laid down under the existing law.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): (i) Mr Speaker, Sir, the Workmen's Compensation Act provides that the workman who suffers as a result of an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment shall be entitled to compensation. The compensation is related to the loss of earning capacity and is intended to be a substitute income contributed by the employer. In addition, the employer is required to bear medical costs arising out of a workman's hospitalisation and treatment, including artificial and surgical appliances.

    According to the Act, the injured worker is entitled to compensation, regardless of whether or not he is responsible for the accident. Members will no doubt agree that this is a practical and realistic approach to the question of compensation. However, the worker has the option of proceeding to claim damages in the Civil Courts if he feels that the liability for the accident can be attributed to the employer or a third party.

    The Member for Kallang will no doubt agree that whatever the quantum of compensation, it can never fully compensate the worker who sustains an injury resulting in permanent disablement. Moreover, compensation on the lines suggested by the Member will present numerous difficulties in practice, such as quantifying the compensation payable for such intangible ill-effects like pain, shock, mortification, humiliation and loss of standing in the

Column: 466

community. However, may I assure the Member that practical suggestions from him would always be given due consideration by the Ministry.

    (ii) Members will recall that the Workmen's Compensation (Amendment) Act, 1971, passed by Parliament on the 19th October, 1971, had increased considerably, in fact, threefold in most cases the quantum of workmen's compensation payable to workmen and their dependants. Under the amended provisions, a workman above the age of 18 years would be entitled to a sum of $28,800, or a lump sum equivalent to 60 months' earnings, whichever is the less, for injuries resulting in total permanent incapacity. The Act also specifies separate rates of compensation payable to workmen below the age of 18 years and those below the age of 16 years. In addition to the compensation for total permanent incapacity, the Act provides that the workman would also receive an additional one-quarter of the computed sum where he is unable to perform the essential actions of life without the constant attention of another person.

    In view of the very recent amendments providing for increased quantum of compensation, the time is not opportune for further amendments to the Workmen's Compensation Act.

    Instead of hankering over the quantum of compensation, may I suggest that it would be more fruitful for all concerned to concentrate their time and energy in getting the trade unions and the workers to play a more active and constructive role in the prevention of accidents. This could be done through education of the workers and by exerting greater pressures upon the employers to provide for a safer and healthier working environment. As many accidents were due to the irresponsibility of the employers as well as the negligence on the part of the workers and their stubbornness and resistance to using protective apparels and other safety devices, I would like to count on the support of the Member

Column: 467

for Kallang when Government prosecutes such recalcitrant employers and workers for infringements of the provisions of the Factories Act and the regulations made thereunder.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have much to educate the employers too. What I want to know is: will the Government be prepared to undertake a claim for damages for and on behalf of an injured workman if, on the face of it, there is evidence to show that his employer had partly or wholly contributed to the cause of the industrial accident which resulted in his sustaining an injury?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, as I said in my answer earlier, workmen's compensation does not take into consideration who is at fault. However, if the injured worker feels that he is not responsible, but that there is a third party involved, or that the employer is responsible, then he can take the case up to the Civil Court.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, will the Government spare an injured workman all the ordeal and legal expenses incurred in securing a claim for damages?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, as provided for, claims can be made under the Workmen's Compensation Act. But if the injured workman wants to take other courses which are open to him, then I am afraid he will have to follow the procedure as laid down in the Courts of Law.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, if I may ask a last supplementary question. The principles that I have laid down are found to be practicable in certain countries. Will the Government accept my proposition in the final analysis?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, as I have said earlier, I assure the Member that any practical suggestions that he has to make are welcome and will be given due consideration, and will he please put them up in writing.

SINGAPORE INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
(Construction of second runway)


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications whether his Ministry has come to a final decision on the construction of a second runway for the Singapore Airport; where will it be constructed; and when construction is expected to commence.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on the basis of the present rate of growth of air traffic in Singapore, my Ministry anticipates that a second runway would be needed around 1977 or 1978. The utilisation rate of the present runway capacity at Paya Lebar is around 40 per cent and is increasing rapidly.

    Last year, 41,241 commercial aircraft, two million passengers, 25.5 million kilograms of freight and 2.8 million kilograms of mail, passed through the Paya Lebar Airport. This represents an increase of approximately 20 per cent, 20 per cent, 21 per cent and a drop of 10 per cent respectively over the 1970 performance.

    As the second runway is needed around 1977-78, construction will have to commence around 1974. Therefore, the Department of Civil Aviation is proceeding with work to build the second runway at the Singapore International Airport at Paya Lebar.

RENEWAL OF CLASS IV DRIVING LICENCES
(Imposition of limit in unladen weight)


    4. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications (a) if he knows to the best of his knowledge that persons who had been granted class 4 licences under the Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules, 1948, which qualified them to drive heavy motor cars with no maximum limit in unladen weight, have on renewal of their licences been granted a similar class licence under the Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules, 1969, which

Column: 469

automatically disqualified and debarred them from driving vehicles exceeding 7 tons in unladen weight; (b) if he is aware that it is common occurrence that holders of class 4 heavy motor car licences are still driving vehicles exceeding 7 tons in unladen weight with the full knowledge, but with no valid authority; of the Registrar of Vehicles; and (c) in view of the fact that such persons might be committing road traffic offences and might face serious consequences, if he will take urgent steps to restore to such persons, who held class 4 heavy motor car licences granted under the Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules, 1948, their status and qualification in all fairness to them and in the interest of the general public in the other respect.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Registry of Vehicles driving licence records were being computerised on 1st February, 1969, the 1948 Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules were replaced by the 1969 Rules. In order to streamline the driving licence records and to facilitate issuance of driving licences, the classification for motor vehicles was at the same time reduced from nine to five classes.

    It is true that persons issued with Class IV licences under the old rules were allowed to drive heavy motor-cars with no maximum limit in the unladen weight, whereas persons issued with Class IV licences under the new rules are not licensed to drive heavy motorcars above seven tons, for which a Class V licence is required. This, however, does not mean that under the Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules, 1969, those who had acquired Class IV driving licences before 1st February, 1969 are being automatically disqualified and debarred from driving heavy motor-cars above seven tons. The validity of licences issued under the 1948 Rules is not affected, as the 1969 Rules were not introduced with retrospective effect. In addition, there is a saving clause under Rule 17 (3) of the Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences)

Column: 470

Rules, 1969, which provides that the new rules do not alter the classes of motor vehicles which a holder of a licence has been licensed to drive before the date when the new rules come into operation. Those issued with Class 1V licences before 1st February, 1969 are, therefore, legally entitled to drive heavy motor-cars above seven tons. The question of restoring to these people their status and qualifications to drive vehicles above seven tons, therefore, does not arise.

    In reducing the classes of vehicles from nine to five, an unfortunate anomaly was created when those persons issued with Class IV licences prior to 1st February, 1969 renewed the old licences for new ones, as the new driving licences contained a pre-printed description of all the five classes of vehicles as defined under the new rules. In this description, Class IV vehicles are defined as heavy motor-cars above 2j tons up to seven tons, although these people are legally entitled to drive heavy motor-cars above seven tons as they had X been granted licences prior to 1st February, 1969.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to express my gratitude and thanks to the Member for Kallang for being so alert and drawing the attention of my Department to this anomaly. The necessary amending Rules re-classifying the classes of motor vehicles under the 1969 Rules to make driving licences issued under the 1948 and 1969 Motor Vehicles (Driving Licences) Rules equitable, have been published in the Government Gazette on 25th February, 1972. Action will also be taken by the Registrar of Vehicles to change the pre-printed description of the five classes of vehicles as contained in the new driving licences.

PORT OF SINGAPORE AUTHORITY
(Bonus payments to monthly-rated employees)


    5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications whether the operational profits of the Port of

Column: 471

Singapore Authority in 1970 would enable the Authority to pay a bonus for productivity to its monthly-rated employees; and whether the Authority is considering paying such bonus, just as it had paid a bonus to such employees in the past, and if the bonus will be paid as soon as possible.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, since the Member for Anson has used the term "operational profits" of the Port of Singapore Authority for the year 1970, may I state that the term `profits' would appear to be a misnomer and the word `surplus' would perhaps be more appropriate for the situation. We generally talk of `profits' of a commercial organisation, which will be distributed amongst shareholders or the staff. But in regard to surpluses, if any, of a statutory organisation like the P.S.A., these will be reinvested for further development.

    As an example, may I refer the Member for Anson to Supplements 1/72 and 2/72 of the Government Gazette dated 28th January, 1972, where it will be noted that whereas the Revenue for P.S.A, for 1972 is estimated at $144 million with a net surplus of $51 million, the estimated Capital Expenditure for the same period will be no less than $63 million.

    Coming now to bonus, the Minister of State for Finance has previously made clear the Government's stand with regard to payment of bonuses to its employees. As a statutory board, the P.S.A, must conform generally to Government's policy on matters relating to remuneration, terms and conditions of service. This means that bonuses for P.S.A. employees cannot be considered, but any betterment in the remuneration and terms and conditions of service of Government employees might, as far as is applicable, be extended to P.S.A, employees.

BRITISH FORCES' HOSPITALS
HANDED OVER ON WITHDRAWAL
(Adequacy of staff)


    13. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health whether there are adequate staff to run the hospitals which have been handed over by the British Forces on their withdrawal from Singapore; and, if not, if his Ministry is taking steps to recruit more staff for those hospitals.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, two hospitals were taken over from the British Forces and they are:

Column: 478



    (a) The Sembawang Hospital (formerly known as the Naval Base Hospital) has a total of 62 available beds for in-patient care. All beds have been commissioned for use, and report 50 per cent occupancy, at the present moment. For this hospital, staff have been approved under Head A/C Code 1202 of the Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure for 1971-72. The full complement is presently not deployed into the hospital as renovations to various departments have not been completed, and the hospital is not running at full strength as yet.

    (b) As for the Alexandra Hospital (formerly the British Military Hospital) which was handed over in early September, it admitted its first patient on the 15th September, 1971. More than 50 per cent of the staff of all grades, as approved under the Estimates, are already working within the hospital. Employment against vacant posts is being programmed to meet the needs of the hospital as it continues to expand its activities.
